1517    /**
1518     *  <p>{@summary Surrounds the given String with double-quotes
1519     *  (&quot;, &amp;#34;).}</p>
1520     *  <p>When the double-quote is needed in a String constant, it has to be
1521     *  escaped with a backslash:</p>
1522     *  <pre><code>&quot;\&quot;â¦\&quot;&quot;</code></pre>
1523     *  <p>Sometimes, this is just ugly, and there this method comes into
1524     *  play.</p>
1525     *
1526     *  @param  input   The String to surround; can be {@code null}.
1527     *  @return The quoted String; will be {@code null} if the argument was
1528     *      {@code null} already.
1529     */
1530    public static final String quote( final CharSequence input )
1531    {
1532        final var retValue = isNull( input ) ? null : String.format( "\"%s\"", input );
1533
1534        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1535        return retValue;
1536    }   //  quote()
1537
1538    /**
1539     *  <p>{@summary This method replaces all diacritical characters in the
1540     *  input String by their base form.} That means that 'Ã¼' gets 'u', `Ã'
1541     *  gets 'E' and so on).</p>
1542     *  <p>This differs from
1543     *  {@link #normalizeToASCII(CharSequence)}
1544     *  as this method still allows non-ASCII characters in the output.</p>
1545     *
1546     *  @note   The scandinavian letters 'Ã¸' and 'Ã' are not diacritical
1547     *      letters, meaning they will not be replaced.
1548     *
1549     *  @param  input   The input string.
1550     *  @return The normalised String, not containing any diacritical
1551     *      characters.
1552     *
1553     *  TODO Check the implementation and the results!! 2022-12-10
1554     */
1555    public static final String removeDiacriticalMarks( final CharSequence input )
1556    {
1557        final var retValue = normalize( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ), NFD )
1558            .replaceAll("\\p{InCombiningDiacriticalMarks}+", EMPTY_STRING );
1559
1560        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1561        return retValue;
1562    }   //  removeDiacriticalMarks()
1563
1564    /**
1565     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat} to form a new String. The table
1566     *  below shows the various  result for some argument combinations.<br>
1567     *  <br><code>
1568     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1569     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
1570     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1571     *  </code>
1572     *
1573     *  @param  c   The character to repeat.
1574     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
1575     *      value will be treated as zero.
1576     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
1577     *      {@code count} times, or the empty String if {@code count} was 0
1578     *      or negative.
1579     *
1580     *  @see String#repeat(int)
1581     *
1582     *  @since 0.0.5
1583     */
1584    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1585    public static final String repeat( final char c, final int count )
1586    {
1587        final var retValue = ( count > 0 ? Character.toString( c ).repeat( count ) : EMPTY_STRING).intern();
1588
1589        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1590        return retValue;
1591    }   //  repeat()
1592
1593    /**
1594     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat}, identified by its code point, to
1595     *  form a new String. The
1596     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
1597     *  combinations.<br>
1598     *  <br><code>
1599     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1600     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
1601     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1602     *  </code>
1603     *
1604     *  @param  codePoint   The character to repeat.
1605     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
1606     *      value will be treated as zero.
1607     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
1608     *      {@code count} times, or the empty String if {@code count} was 0
1609     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the code point is invalid.
1610     *
1611     *  @see Character#isValidCodePoint(int)
1612     *  @see String#repeat(int)
1613     *
1614     *  @since 0.0.5
1615     */
1616    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1617    public static final String repeat( final int codePoint, final int count )
1618    {
1619        final var retValue = (count > 0)
1620            ? isValidCodePoint( codePoint )
1621                ? Character.toString( codePoint ).repeat( count ).intern()
1622                : null
1623            : EMPTY_STRING;
1624
1625        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1626        return retValue;
1627    }   //  repeat()
1628
1629    /**
1630     *  Repeats the given String {@code repeat} times to form a new String. The
1631     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
1632     *  combinations.<br>
1633     *  <br><code>
1634     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;null,&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;null<br>
1635     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1636     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1637     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
1638     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"ab",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"abab"<br>
1639     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
1640     *  </code>
1641     *
1642     *  @param  input The String to repeat, may be {@code null}.
1643     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code str}; a negative
1644     *      value will be treated as zero.
1645     *  @return A new String consisting of the original String repeated,
1646     *      {@code count} times, the empty String if {@code count} was 0
1647     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the input String was
1648     *      {@code null}, too.
1649     *
1650     *  @see String#repeat(int)
1651     *
1652     *  @since 0.0.5
1653     */
1654    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1655    public static final String repeat( final CharSequence input, final int count )
1656    {
1657        final var retValue =
1658            nonNull( input )
1659                ? (count > 0) && !input.isEmpty()
1660                    ? input.toString().repeat( count )
1661                    : EMPTY_STRING
1662                : null;
1663
1664        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1665        return retValue;
1666    }   //  repeat()
1667
1668    /**
1669     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
1670     *  returns an array of all parts.} In case a separator character is
1671     *  immediately followed by another separator character, an empty String
1672     *  will be placed to the array.</p>
1673     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1674     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
1675     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
1676     *  last character is a separator.</p>
1677     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
1678     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
1679     *
1680     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1681     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
1682     *  @return The parts of the String.
1683     *
1684     *  @since 0.0.5
1685     */
1686    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1687    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final char separator )
1688    {
1689        return splitString( input, (int) separator );
1690    }   //  splitString()
1691
1692    /**
1693     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character,
1694     *  identified by its Unicode code point, and returns an array of all
1695     *  parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
1696     *  another separator character, an empty String will be placed to the
1697     *  array.</p>
1698     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1699     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
1700     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
1701     *  last character is a separator.</p>
1702     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
1703     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
1704     *
1705     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1706     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
1707     *  @return The parts of the String.
1708     *
1709     *  @since 0.0.5
1710     */
1711    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1712    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final int separator )
1713    {
1714        final var retValue = stream( input, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
1715
1716        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1717        return retValue;
1718    }   //  splitString()
1719
1720    /**
1721     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator sequence and
1722     *  returns an array of all parts.} In case a separator sequence is
1723     *  immediately followed by another separator sequence, an empty String
1724     *  will be placed to the array.</p>
1725     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1726     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
1727     *  array will start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty
1728     *  String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
1729     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
1730     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
1731     *
1732     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1733     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
1734     *  @return The parts of the String.
1735     *
1736     *  @since 0.0.5
1737     */
1738    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1739    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final CharSequence separator )
1740    {
1741        final var retValue = stream( input, separator).toArray( String []::new );
1742
1743        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1744        return retValue;
1745    }   //  splitString()
1746
1747    /**
1748     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
1749     *  returns an instance of
1750     *  {@link Stream}
1751     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately
1752     *  followed by another separator character, an empty String will be put to
1753     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
1754     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1755     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned
1756     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
1757     *  empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
1758     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
1759     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
1760     *  empty.</p>
1761     *
1762     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1763     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
1764     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
1765     *
1766     *  @since 0.0.7
1767     */
1768    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
1769    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final char separator )
1770    {
1771        return stream( input, (int) separator );
1772    }   //  stream()
1773
1774    /**
1775     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
1776     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
1777     *  {@link Stream}
1778     *  of all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
1779     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
1780     *  {@code Stream}.</p>
1781     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as
1782     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
1783     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
1784     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
1785     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
1786     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
1787     *  empty.</p>
1788     *
1789     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1790     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
1791     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
1792     *
1793     *  @since 0.0.7
1794     */
1795    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
1796    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final int separator )
1797    {
1798        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
1799        final var codepoints = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).codePoints().toArray();
1800        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
1801        var begin = -1;
1802        for( var i = 0 ; i < codepoints.length; ++i )
1803        {
1804            if( begin == -1 )
1805            {
1806                begin = i;
1807            }
1808            if( codepoints [i] == separator )
1809            {
1810                builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
1811                begin = -1;
1812            }
1813        }
1814
1815        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
1816        if( begin >= 0 )
1817        {
1818            builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, codepoints.length - begin ).intern() );
1819        }
1820        if( (codepoints.length == 0) || (codepoints [codepoints.length - 1] == separator) )
1821        {
1822            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
1823        }
1824
1825        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
1826        final var retValue = builder.build();
1827
1828        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1829        return retValue;
1830    }   //  stream()
1831
1832    /**
1833     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator sequence and
1834     *  returns an instance of
1835     *  {@link Stream}
1836     *  containing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
1837     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
1838     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
1839     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1840     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
1841     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
1842     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
1843     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
1844     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
1845     *  empty.</p>
1846     *
1847     *  @param  input   The String to split.
1848     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
1849     *  @return The parts of the String.
1850     *
1851     *  @since 0.0.7
1852     */
1853    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
1854    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final CharSequence separator )
1855    {
1856        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
1857        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
1858        var s = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString();
1859        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
1860        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
1861
1862        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
1863        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
1864        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
1865        {
1866            pos = s.indexOf( t );
1867            switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
1868            {
1869                case 0 -> /* String starts with separator */
1870                    {
1871                        builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
1872                        s = s.substring( t.length() );
1873                    }
1874                case 1 -> /* String contains a separator somewhere */
1875                    {
1876                        builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
1877                        s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
1878                    }
1879                default -> { /* Just leave the loop */ }
1880            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
1881        }
1882
1883        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
1884        builder.add( s );
1885
1886        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
1887        final var retValue = builder.build();
1888
1889        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1890        return retValue;
1891    }   //  stream()
1892
1893    /**
1894     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String using the given regular expression and
1895     *  returns an instance of
1896     *  {@link Stream}
1897     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
1898     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
1899     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
1900     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
1901     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
1902     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
1903     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
1904     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
1905     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
1906     *  empty.</p>
1907     *
1908     *  @note This method behaves different from
1909     *      {@link String#split(String)}
1910     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
1911     *
1912     *  @param  input  The String to split.
1913     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
1914     *  @return The parts of the String.
1915     *
1916     *  @see String#split(String)
1917     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
1918     *
1919     *  @since 0.0.7
1920     */
1921    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
1922    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final Pattern pattern )
1923    {
1924        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
1925
1926        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
1927        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
1928        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( input, "s" ) ) )
1929        {
1930            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
1931        }
1932        else
1933        {
1934            final var parts = pattern.split( input );
1935            for( final var part : parts )
1936            {
1937                builder.add( part );
1938            }
1939            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( input );
1940            var count = 0;
1941            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
1942            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
1943            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
1944            {
1945                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
1946            }
1947        }
1948
1949        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
1950        final var retValue = builder.build();
1951
1952        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1953        return retValue;
1954    }   //  stream()
1955
1956    /**
1957     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
1958     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
1959     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
1960     *  blanks).<br>
1961     *  <br>This means that the result for
1962     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
1963     *      &lt;head&gt;
1964     *        &hellip;
1965     *      &lt;/head&gt;
1966     *      &lt;body&gt;
1967     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
1968     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
1969     *      &lt;/body&gt;
1970     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
1971     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
1972     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
1973     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
1974     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
1975     *
1976     *  @param  input   The HTML/XML string.
1977     *  @return The string without the tags.
1978     *
1979     *  @since 0.0.7
1980     */
1981    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1982    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence input )
1983    {
1984        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
1985        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ) ) )
1986        {
1987            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( input );
1988            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
1989            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
1990            ScanLoop: for( final var codePoint : buffer )
1991            {
1992                if( isWhitespace( codePoint ) )
1993                {
1994                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
1995                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
1996
1997                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
1998                    retValue.append( " " );
1999                }
2000                else
2001                {
2002                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2003                    retValue.append( toChars( codePoint ) );
2004                }
2005                lastChar = codePoint;
2006            }   //  ScanLoop:
2007        }
2008
2009        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2010        return retValue.toString();
2011    }   //  stripTags()
2012
2013    /**
2014     *  <p>{@summary Strips characters from the given input that are not
2015     *  allowed (or should be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on
2016     *  most or all operating systems.}</p>
2017     *  <p>The following characters will be stripped:</p>
2018     *  <dl>
2019     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2020     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2021     *  systems (including MacOS) it would be valid, but it can cause issues on
2022     *  the {@code PATH} and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on these operating
2023     *  systems.</dd>
2024     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2025     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2026     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2027     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2028     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2029     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2030     *  systems, too.</dd>
2031     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2032     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2033     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2034     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2035     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2036     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2037     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2038     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2039     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2040     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2041     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2042     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2043     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2044     *  file.</dd>
2045     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2046     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2047     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2048     *  character in their names.</dd>
2049     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2050     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2051     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2052     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2053     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2054     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2055     *  </dl>
2056     *  <p>Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2057     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2058     *  surrounded by some visible characters.</p>
2059     *  <p>Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells
2060     *  ('*', '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2061     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2062     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.</p>
2063     *  <p>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2064     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2065     *  where this is not true.</p>
2066     *
2067     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2068     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2069     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2070     *
2071     *  @param  input   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2072     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2073     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2074     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2075     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2076     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2077     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2078     *      return value would be empty.
2079     *
2080     *  @since 0.0.5
2081     */
2082    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2083    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2084    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence input ) throws ValidationException
2085    {
2086        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( input, "input" ).length();
2087        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2088        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2089        {
2090            final var currentCharacter = input.charAt( i );
2091            Selector:
2092            //noinspection SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches,EnhancedSwitchMigration
2093            switch( currentCharacter )
2094            {
2095                case ':':
2096                case '\\':
2097                case '/':
2098                case ';':
2099                case '*':
2100                case '"':
2101                case '\'':
2102                case '@':
2103                case '|':
2104                case '?':
2105                case '<':
2106                case '>':
2107                    continue ScanLoop;
2108
2109                default:
2110                {
2111                    if( (currentCharacter == ' ') || (!isISOControl( currentCharacter ) && !isWhitespace( currentCharacter )) )
2112                    {
2113                        buffer.append( currentCharacter );
2114                    }
2115                    break Selector;
2116                }
2117            }   //  Selector:
2118        }   //  ScanLoop:
2119
2120        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2121        if( retValue.isEmpty() )
2122        {
2123            throw new ValidationException( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name".formatted(  input.toString() ) );
2124        }
2125
2126        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2127        return retValue;
2128    }   //  stripToFilename()
2129
2130    /**
2131     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2132     *
2133     *  @param  input   The HTML/XML string.
2134     *  @return The string without the comments.
2135     *
2136     *  @since 0.0.5
2137     */
2138    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2139    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence input )
2140    {
2141        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ) );
2142        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2143
2144        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2145        return retValue;
2146    }   //  stripXMLComments()

2148    /**
2149     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2150     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2151     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2152     *  <br>For example, the string
2153     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2154     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2155     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2156     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2157     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2158     *
2159     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2160     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2161     *      string was already {@code null}.
2162     *
2163     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2164     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2165     *
2166     *  @since 0.0.5
2167     */

2169    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence input )
2170    {
2171        final var retValue = nonNull( input ) ? HTML50.unescape( input ) : null;
2172
2173        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2174        return retValue;

2185     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>

2187     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2188     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.

2239     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2240     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2241     *
2242     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.

2259    /**
2260     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
2261     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
2262     *  <br>Internally, this method and
2263     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
2264     *  make use of the methods from
2265     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
2266     *  and
2267     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
2268     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
2269     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
2270     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
2271     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
2272     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
2273     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
2274     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
2275     *
2276     *  @param  input   The input String.
2277     *  @return The decoded result.
2278     *
2279     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
2280     *
2281     *  @since 0.0.5
2282     */
2283    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2284    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence input )
2285    {
2286        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2287
2288        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2289        return retValue;
2290    }   //  urlDecode()
2291
2292    /**
2293     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
2294     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
2295     *
2296     *  @param  input   The input String.
2297     *  @return The URL encoded result.
2298     *
2299     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
2300     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
2301     *
2302     *  @since 0.0.5
2303     */
2304    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2305    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence input )
2306    {
2307        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2308
2309        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2310        return retValue;
2311    }   //  urlEncode()
2312}
2313//  class StringUtils
2314

2316 *    End of File
2317 */
